articles.author: HANNA ARHIROVA
articles.description: KYIV, Ukraine (AP) — Fierce fighting raged Thursday in southeastern Ukraine, where a Western official said Kyiv has launched a major push and Russian President Vladimir Putin said “hostilities have intensified significantly.”
articles.title: Putin says fighting in southeastern Ukraine has intensified, with heavy losses for Kyiv's forces

articles.author: The Associated Press
articles.description: Sometime this summer, if President Vladimir Putin can be believed, Russia moved some of its short-range nuclear weapons into Belarus, closer to Ukraine and onto NATO's doorstep.
articles.title: Bluffing or not, Putin’s declared deployment of nuclear weapons to Belarus raises tensions

articles.author: PAUL WISEMAN
articles.description: WASHINGTON (AP) — The U.S. economy accelerated unexpectedly to a 2.4% annual growth rate from April through June, showing continued resilience in the face of steadily higher interest rates resulting from the Federal Reserve’s 16-month-long fight against inflation.
articles.title: US economy grew at a faster 2.4% rate in April-June quarter despite Fed rate hikes

articles.author: JILL COLVIN
articles.description: NEW YORK (AP) — The day after Jan. 6, 2021, then-President Donald Trump denounced the rioters who violently stormed the Capitol building, breaking through barricades, battling law enforcement and sending members of Congress — who were set to formally certify his reelection loss — running for their lives.
articles.title: Trump once condemned the Jan. 6 rioters. Now he's become one of their biggest supporters

articles.author: CLAUDIA LAUER, RANDALL CHASE and COLLEEN LONG
articles.description: WILMINGTON, Del. (AP) — The plea deal in Hunter Biden’s criminal case unraveled during a court hearing Wednesday after a federal judge raised concerns about the terms of the agreement that has infuriated Republicans who believe the president’s son is getting preferential treatment.
articles.title: Hunter Biden's plea deal on hold after federal judge raises concerns over the terms of the agreement

articles.author: The Associated Press
articles.description: More than 1,000 U.S. service personnel are in Niger, which until Wednesday's coup attempt by mutinous soldiers had avoided the military takeovers that destabilized West African neighbors in recent years.
articles.title: How the attempted coup in Niger could expand the reach of extremism, and Wagner, in West Africa

articles.author: CHRIS MEGERIAN, DREW COSTLEY and MATTHEW DALY
articles.description: WASHINGTON (AP) — With millions of Americans facing broiling heat across the Southwest, President Joe Biden on Thursday plans to announce new steps to protect workers, improve weather forecasts and make drinking water more accessible, the White House says.
articles.title: Biden looks to provide relief from extreme heat as record temperatures persist across US

articles.author: TIA GOLDENBERG and ISAAC SCHARF
articles.description: JERUSALEM (AP) — Israeli military fire killed a 14-year-old Palestinian boy in the occupied West Bank, Palestinian health officials said Thursday, as an ultranationalist Israeli Cabinet minister visited a sensitive Jerusalem holy site that has been a frequent flashpoint for violence between Israel and the Palestinians.
articles.title: Army fire kills a 14-year-old, Palestinians say, as an Israeli minister visits flashpoint holy site

articles.author: BRIAN MELLEY
articles.description: LONDON (AP) — Prince Harry’s lawsuit accusing the publisher of The Sun tabloid of unlawfully snooping on him can go to trial, but not on claims of phone hacking, a High Court judge ruled Thursday.The Duke of Sussex alleged the publisher of The Sun and the now-defunct News Of The World had hacked his phone and used investigators and deception to unlawfully gather information on him dating back two decades.
articles.title: Judge allows Prince Harry's snooping lawsuit against publisher of The Sun tabloid to go to trial

articles.author: BARBARA ORTUTAY
articles.description: SAN FRANCISCO (AP) — Elon Musk may want to send “tweet” back to the birds, but the ubiquitous term for posting on the site he now calls X is here to stay — at least for now.
articles.title: Elon Musk wants to turn tweets into 'X's'. But changing language is not quite so simple
